docs.abstract: Superstitions can be a form of prayer, as well as an exorcism in miniature.
docs.snippet: Superstitions can be a form of prayer, as well as an exorcism in miniature.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Hey,” a new acquaintance said to me shortly after I moved to Portland, Ore. “I think I saw you running by the river yesterday.” He was frowning a little, as if fact-checking the memory. “Did you jump up like Michael Jordan to touch a leaf?”

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on calling the cops on a black man breaking into a car and selling your condo to someone accused of sexual assault.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on calling the cops on a black man breaking into a car and selling your condo to someone accused of sexual assault.
docs.lead_paragraph: Recently, I witnessed a young black male cut across my yard, duck between my neighbors’ two cars and try the doors of both, before “breaking” into the unlocked one. I opened my back door and yelled, “I see you getting into that car!” He took off running. I called the police and then posted to the (admittedly sometimes racially charged) Nextdoor app, in the hopes that my neighbors would check the locks on their cars and homes.

headline.main: Was I Right to Call the Cops on a Black Man Breaking Into a Car?
headline.print_headline: Was I Right to Call the Cops on a Black Man Breaking Into a Car?

docs.abstract: Radical militias want to convince you to fear ‘an invasion.’ When they’re the ones holding the guns, their performance calls attention to a more immediate danger.
docs.snippet: Radical militias want to convince you to fear ‘an invasion.’ When they’re the ones holding the guns, their performance calls attention to a more immediate danger.
docs.lead_paragraph: At times the whole screen is black, except for the darting white disc created by a flashlight. Through that peephole filter adults and children, in slacks and lightweight jackets, with few bags to be seen. They are migrants, possibly from Central America. “See the way they hold their kids?” asks the woman streaming this video on Facebook Live. “I don’t think those are their kids, honestly. They’ve got grips on their wrists, it’s crazy.” The people are sandwiched between Border Patrol trucks, illuminated by flashing lights. “There’s gotta be more like 400 here,” she says.

headline.main: The Real Threat Uncovered by Armed Civilians at the Border

docs.abstract: Get a mile inland or 100 feet above sea level. If in the water, grab something that floats. Don’t give up.
docs.snippet: Get a mile inland or 100 feet above sea level. If in the water, grab something that floats. Don’t give up.
docs.lead_paragraph: “At the first warning, you should run inland as fast as you can and get as high as you can,” says Fal Allen, who had no such opportunity as a 14-year-old boy scout on an overnight beach outing in Hawaii in 1975, when an earthquake jolted the campers awake. The boys could hear boulders tumbling down the cliffs behind them, so they crawled toward the ocean to avoid being crushed. “We looked up,” Allen says, “and it was just this wall of water coming at us.”

docs.abstract: Images for the Notes on the Culture item on designer Joseph Altuzarra’s collection of owls.
docs.snippet: Images for the Notes on the Culture item on designer Joseph Altuzarra’s collection of owls.
docs.lead_paragraph: Images for the Notes on the Culture item on designer Joseph Altuzarra’s collection of owls.

headline.main: Of a Kind: Joseph Altuzarra’s Owls

docs.slideshow_credits: Illustration by Aurora de la Morinerie

docs.abstract: The documentary series based on Dr. Lisa Sanders’s column for The New York Times Magazine is now live.
docs.snippet: The documentary series based on Dr. Lisa Sanders’s column for The New York Times Magazine is now live.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Lisa Sanders is an associate professor at the Yale University School of Medicine who also writes about medical mysteries for The New York Times Magazine. Her column, which she has written since 2002, follows patients with unusual symptoms as they search for diagnoses that can change their lives.

headline.main: Introducing ‘Diagnosis,’ a New Show From The Times and Netflix

docs.abstract: If a relative or friend of yours served, help us get in touch with them. Or, if you served during World War II, tell us about your experience directly.
docs.snippet: If a relative or friend of yours served, help us get in touch with them. Or, if you served during World War II, tell us about your experience directly.
docs.lead_paragraph: Next year marks the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II. To commemorate a conflict that changed the course of world history, we want to hear from World War II veterans, especially those who served in nontraditional roles, for a Times project that will involve both text and photography. Millions of Americans aided the war effort in unconventional or unsung ways. Too often, these stories are left untold.

headline.main: Do You Have a Living Relative Who Served in World War II? Help Us Tell Their Story

docs.abstract: In the pool, by the sea, tales of long summer days on the water.
docs.snippet: In the pool, by the sea, tales of long summer days on the water.
docs.lead_paragraph: Longer, warmer days are finally here, and the beach beckons. But what makes a beach trip truly unforgettable? We asked five writers for their favorite memories about sand, surf and summertime.

headline.main: 5 Writers on the Summers They Will Never Forget

docs.abstract: Elongate your neck. Find your good side. Don’t say “cheese.”
docs.snippet: Elongate your neck. Find your good side. Don’t say “cheese.”
docs.lead_paragraph: “You look your most attractive when you have a strong jawline,” says Peter Hurley, a portrait photographer in New York City who has taken head shots for some 30,000 people, including the likes of Mikhail Baryshnikov and Ariana Grande. To accentuate and define your jaw, elongate your body and neck by imagining you’re being pulled up by a string attached to the top of your head. Once you’ve giraffed yourself to the best of your ability, jut your forehead and chin toward the camera.

headline.main: How to Pose for a Photograph
headline.print_headline: How to Pose for a Photograph

docs.abstract: Do you have a photo of war graffiti from a deployment? Share it with us for a coming story.
docs.snippet: Do you have a photo of war graffiti from a deployment? Share it with us for a coming story.
docs.lead_paragraph: From the Civil War to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, American soldiers have left memes, phallic imagery and the denunciations of rival units in their wake. Jonathan Bratten follows the history of soldiers’ graffiti over more than 150 years of conflict and how it has come to define military culture with its own vocabulary, characters and aesthetics.

headline.main: Graffiti of War: Send Us Your Favorite Photos
